subject: mathematics
overview: Primary 1 mathematics is delivered through 12 themes, emphasizing practical counting, number recognition, basic operations, and measurement using manipulatives and real-world contexts.
learning_outcomes: Sort objects into sets and count accurately within 10
Recognize and write numbers to at least 20
Perform simple addition and subtraction using concrete materials
Identify and name basic 2D and 3D shapes
Use non-standard units to measure and compare lengths and masses
Apply mathematical thinking to everyday problem-solving

themes.name: Our School
competences: Sorting into sets (e.g., different activities at school)

themes.name: Our Home
competences: Identifying simple shapes in household objects

themes.name: Our Community
competences: Counting people and objects in the community
Matching community helpers to their roles

themes.name: The Human Body and Health
competences: Matching left and right body parts

themes.name: Weather
competences: Recording weather patterns with tally marks

themes.name: Accidents and Safety
competences: Using positional language for safety (under, over, around)

themes.name: Living Together
competences: Sorting people by roles (mother, teacher, etc.)
Using numbers in social contexts (age, order of siblings)

themes.name: Food And Nutrition
competences: Sorting foods by groups (grains, vegetables, fruits, proteins)
Counting food items (fruits on a plate)
Using non-standard units to measure food (handful, spoonful)

themes.name: Our Transport
competences: Sorting transport by type (land, water, air)

themes.name: Things We Make
competences: Sorting craft materials by type or color
Arranging items in patterns and designs

themes.name: Peace And Security
competences: Using positional language in community spaces

teaching_methodology: Use of manipulatives (counters, blocks, beads) for concrete learning
Games and playful activities for number concept development
Group and pair work with mathematical discussions
Songs and rhymes to reinforce number sequences
assessment_focus: Observe children's ability to sort and count accurately
Check understanding of number concepts, not memorization
Use work samples (drawings, arrangements) as evidence
resources: Real objects from themes (food, transport models, etc.)
Tally cards and simple recording sheets
Picture cards for matching and sequencing
notes: Mathematics in P1 is integrated within themes to make learning meaningful. Competences are demonstrated through practical activities, not written tests. Children learn through exploration, experimentation, and play. All assessment is informal and observational in the local language.
